[[Ole Miss Rebels football|Ole Miss Rebels]] |- | '''Originated''' | 1908 |- | '''Series''' | Arkansas says it leads, 32â25â1
Ole Miss says Arkansas leads, 31â26â1 |- | '''Current Champion''' | Arkansas |- | '''Most Recent Game''' | Arkansas 29, Ole Miss 24
October 22, 2011 |- | '''Current Streak''' | Arkansas 2 |- | '''Trophy''' |None |- |} The '''ArkansasâOle Miss football rivalry''' is an American [[college football]] rivalry between the [[Arkansas Razorbacks football]] team of the [[University of Arkansas]] and the [[Ole Miss Rebels football]] team of the [[University of Mississippi]]. Although the rivalry currently exists predominantly between the respective programs' [[American football|football]] teams, all men's and women's sports teams of both universities play on an annual basis because the two universities both compete in the [[Southeastern Conference]] (SEC) Western Division. The football teams first met in 1908, and have played each other annually since 1981. Overall, Arkansas currently leads the football series at 31â25â1, which includes two wins by Ole Miss in post-season bowl games, the 1963 and 1970 Sugar Bowls. {{TOClimit|3}} ==History== The rivalry between Arkansas and Ole Miss developed partially due to geography. Besides being neighboring states in the [[southeastern United States]], from the University of Arkansas' perspective, the University of Mississippi is closer in terms of distance than any other Southeastern Conference school. Arkansas has played Ole Miss more than any other SEC opponent. [http://mcubed.net/ncaaf/series/ark/series2.shtml mcubed.net : NFL : Arkansas : Series records] ===Pre 1980s=== The teams were first scheduled to meet each other in 1906, but due to a cancellation, the two teams began play against one another in a 1908 contest in which Arkansas won by a score of 33â0. Arkansas and Mississippi played many times sporadically in the following years. In addition to several single years of playing each other, the two teams played each other from 1940â47 and 1952â62 on an annual basis. The Razorbacks and Rebels also met twice in the [[Sugar Bowl]] played in [[New Orleans]], in 1963 and 1970; Both contests were won by Ole Miss. Especially in the early years, the teams often met in [[Memphis, Tennessee]] to play the game, besides the normal Arkansas and Mississippi game sites. ===1980s to present=== Since 1981, the two teams have played each other annually in football. The games have generally alternated yearly between a site in Mississippi ([[Jackson, Mississippi|Jackson]], or more recently [[Oxford, Mississippi|Oxford]]) and a site in Arkansas ([[Little Rock, Arkansas|Little Rock]], or more recently [[Fayetteville, Arkansas|Fayetteville]]), except for one time in 1995 when the game was played in Memphis, Tennessee. Since Arkansas joined the [[Southeastern Conference]] in 1991 (first football season was 1992; previously a member of the [[Southwestern Conference|SWC]]), the two teams have played annually as both conference and Western division rivals. ===Recently (2000s)=== In 2001, Arkansas and Ole Miss had an NCAA record seven-overtime game in Oxford, MS. Arkansas has had the overall advantage since 2000, winning 8 games to 4 for Ole Miss. ==Houston Nutt controversy== Upon the conclusion of the [[2007 Arkansas Razorbacks football team|2007 regular season]], Arkansas Razorbacks coach [[Houston Nutt]] was forced to resign amid several [[Controversy|controversies]] and allegations that had arisen. [http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2007/writers/stewart_mandel/02/22/arkansas.nutt/index.html SI.com â Writers â Stewart Mandel: Nutt faces heat in truly bizarre Arkansas soap opera â Thursday February 22, 2007 6:10PM] [http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/18321489/ SN: Time for Nutt to bolt Arkansas â College football â MSNBC.com] Hours later, he was announced as the head coach of the Ole Miss Rebels football team[http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=3129559 ESPN â Nutt agrees with Ole Miss hours after resigning from Arkansas â College Football], replacing [[Ed Orgeron]] who had been fired after three consecutive losing seasons. Ole Miss and Arkansas met in [[Fayetteville, Arkansas|Fayetteville]] on October 25, 2008 with identical 3â4 records. This marked Nutt's first return to the University of Arkansas campus as an opposing coach. Nutt led his Rebels to a 23â21 victory over the Razorbacks. The long-standing rivalry has become more interesting because of his association with both universities. ==Game results== The results of games played between Arkansas and Ole Miss: [http://texasfan7.greatnow.com/NCAA_Division_1-A.htm NCAA Football History] [http://football.stassen.com/cgi-bin/records/opp-opp.pl?start=1869&end=2007&team1=Arkansas&team2=Mississippi Arkansas vs Mississippi 1869â2007] [http://mcubed.net/ncaaf/series/ark/ms.shtml mcubed.net : NCAAF Football : Series records : Arkansas vs. Mississippi] ''Arkansas victories are colored ââ red. Ole Miss victories are colored ââ blue. Disputed outcome shaded in ââ grey. Oxford, MS }} |} {{col-end}} '''*'''Arkansas claims "Won by forfeit" while Ole Miss claims "Won on field".
{{note|a}}Played in the [[Sugar Bowl]].
==Notable games== ====1908 â First Meeting==== '''Arkansas 33 â Ole Miss 0''' {{See also|1908 Arkansas_Razorbacks football team}} The very first meeting between the two teams was a 1908 contest in which Arkansas won by a score of 33â0. The teams were first scheduled to meet each other in 1906, but due to a cancellation, the 1908 contest was the first meeting. ====1914 â Contentious result==== Arkansas lists the 1914 contest as a forfeit by Ole Miss because Ole Miss used an ineligible player. Ole Miss denies the allegation of using an ineligible player and therefore lists the contest by the recorded on the field winning score of 13â7 in favor of Ole Miss.http://www.olemisssports.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/102210aaa.html http://arkansas.scout.com/2/318482.html http://olemisssports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/111304aaj.html Therefore, the two school's official records for the overall series shows a one game difference. As of the 2010 Arkansas win, Ole Miss lists the series as 30â26â1 in favor of Arkansas while Arkansas lists the series as 31â25â1 in Arkansas' favor. ====1954 â Powder River Pass==== '''Arkansas 6 â Ole Miss 0''' {{See also|1954 Arkansas Razorbacks football team}} Arkansas and Ole Miss met in [[War Memorial Stadium (Arkansas)|War Memorial Stadium]] on October 23, 1954. The game was scoreless until the Razorbacks called a trick play: a 66-yard halfback pass from halfback Buddy Bob Benson to [[Preston Carpenter]] for the only points of the game. Arkansas head coach [[Bowden Wyatt]] named the play after the [[Powder River (Montana)|Powder River]], a river in his native [[Wyoming]]. The river is a mile wide but deceptively only a foot deep. With the 6â0 win, Arkansas would go on to fall in the [[1955 Cotton Bowl Classic]] against [[Bobby Dodd]]'s Georgia Tech, and the Rebels would continue to the [[1955 Sugar Bowl]], losing to Navy. ====1959==== '''Ole Miss 28 â Arkansas 0''' {{See also|1959 Ole Miss Rebels football team|1959 Arkansas Razorbacks football team}} The 1959 contest was won by Ole Miss 28â0 in Memphis, Tennessee on their way to a final record of 10â1 for the [[1959 college football season|1959 season]] and one of their three claimed [[NCAA Division I-A National Football Championship| national championship]]s. ====1960==== '''Ole Miss 10 â Arkansas 7''' {{See also|1960 Arkansas Razorbacks football team}} The 1960 contest between the teams was won by Ole Miss 10â7 at [[War Memorial Stadium (Arkansas)|War Memorial Stadium]] in [[Little Rock, Arkansas]], on their way to a final record of 10â0â1 for the [[1960 college football season|1960 season]] and the second of their three claimed national championships. Sometimes called the [[Tommy Bell (American football official)|Tommy Bell]] game by Arkansas fans, he called a timeout in an attempt to quiet Razorback fans.Bailey, Jim, and Henry, Orville. "The Razorbacks-A Story of Arkansas Football" Rebel Allen Green did not hear the whistle and kicked the ball through the uprights. After the timeout, fans swear Bell signaled that the kick was good as soon as Green connected with the ball. Fans also swear that the kick was no good. Fighting broke out all around the stadium and because of this, the annual series between the two schools was played the next year in Jackson and then was canceled until the two teams renewed the series in 1981. ====1963 Sugar Bowl with National Championship implications==== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Razorbacks |R1=0|R2=3|R3=10|R4=0 |Home='''Rebels''' |H1=3|H2=7|H3=7|H4=0 }} '''Ole Miss 17 â Arkansas 13''' {{See also|1963 Sugar Bowl|1962 Arkansas Razorbacks football team}} The January 1, 1963 [[1963 Sugar Bowl|Sugar Bowl]] in [[New Orleans, Louisiana|New Orleans]] was played between the two teams as a end to the [[1962 college football season|1962 regular season]]. It was both the Razorbacks' and Rebels' fourth bowl in four seasons, and was the second straight [[Sugar Bowl]] for Arkansas. After each team kicked field goals, Ole Miss scored the first touchdown, a 33 yard strike from [[Glynn Griffing]] to Louis Guy gave the Rebels a 10â3 lead."Ole Miss History and Records." [[University of Mississippi]]. [http://www.olemisssports.com//pdf4/80245.pdf?SPSID=87067&SPID=737&DB_OEM_ID=2600 Ole Miss Bowl History.] Retrieved on [[July 7]]. [[2008]]. The Hogs replied with a five yard touchdown toss from Billy Moore to knot the game at 10. Ole Miss [[Quarterback|QB]] Griffing then scored on a one-yard touchdown scamper. The Razorbacks would tack on a field goal, but neither team could dent the scoreboard in the fourth quarter. Ole Miss won the game by a final score of 17â13 to finish the season 10â0 and win a share of the [[1962 college football season|1962 national championship]] in college football. This was their third of three national championships Ole Miss claims. {{AmFootballScoreSummaryStart|VisitorName=ARK|HomeName=UM|state=collapsed}} {{AmFootballScoreSummaryEntry | Quarter=2 | Time= | Team=UM | DriveLength=80 | DriveTime= | Type=FG | yards=30 | Kicker='''Irwin''' | Visitor=0 | Home=3 }} {{AmFootballScoreSummaryEntry | Quarter=2 | Time= | Team=ARK | DriveLength=82 | DriveTime= | Type=FG | yards=30 | Kicker='''Tom McKnelly''' | Visitor=3 | Home=3 }} {{AmFootballScoreSummaryEntry | Quarter=2 | Time= | Team=UM | DriveLength=67 | DriveTime= | Type=RecTD | Receiver='''Louis Guy''' | yards=33 | QB='''[[Glynn Griffing]]''' | kickresult=good | Kicker=''Irwin'' | Visitor=3 | Home=10 }} {{AmFootballScoreSummaryEntry | Quarter=3 | Time= | Team=ARK | DriveLength=15 | DriveTime= | Type=RecTD | Receiver='''Jesse Branch''' | yards=5 | QB='''Billy Moore''' | kickresult=good | Kicker=''Tom McKnelly'' | Visitor=10 | Home=10 }} {{AmFootballScoreSummaryEntry | Quarter=3 | Time= | Team=UM | DriveLength=80 | DriveTime= | Type=RushTD | yards=1 | Runner='''Glynn Griffing''' | kickresult=good | Kicker=''Irwin'' | Visitor=10 | Home=17 }} {{AmFootballScoreSummaryEntry | Quarter=3 | Time= | Team=ARK | DriveLength=59 | DriveTime= | Type=FG | yards=22 | Kicker='''Tom McKnelly''' | Visitor=13 | Home=17 }} {{AmFootballScoreSummaryEnd|Visitor=13|Home=17}} {{-}} ====2001 â Record 7-Overtime Game==== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road='''Razorbacks''' |R1=0 |R2=7 |R3=3 |R4=7 |R5=7 |R6=0 |R7=6 |R8=6 |R9=6 |R10=8 |R11=8 |Home=Rebels |H1=7 |H2=0 |H3=3 |H4=7 |H5=7 |H6=0 |H7=6 |H8=6 |H9=6 |H10=8 |H11=6 }} '''Arkansas 58 â Ole Miss 56 (7OT)''' {{See also|2001 Arkansas Razorbacks football team|2001 Ole Miss Rebels football team}} On November 3, 2001, Arkansas and Ole Miss played in an [[NCAA]] [[NCAA football overtime records|record]] 7-overtime game in Oxford, MS. The marathon game featured 114 points, 988 offensive yards, four 100-yard rushers, and seven overtimes, with Arkansas prevailing 58â56."Arkansas vs. Ole Miss." [http://www.usatoday.com/sports/scores101/101307/101307402.htm Box Score, Stats, and Game Summary.] USA Today. Nov 3, 2001. Retrieved on August 23, 2008."2001 SEC Football Standings." [http://www.secsports.com/fbo/fbc/01stand.html 2001 SEC Scores.] [[Southeastern Conference|SECsports.com]]. Dec 13, 2001. Retrieved on August 23, 2008. The game started slowly, however, with a 7â7 tie going into halftime. Arkansas completed a field goal attempt in the third quarter, giving the Hogs a 10â7 edge."Arkansas Downs Ole Miss 58â56 in Seven Overtimes." [http://www.arkansasrazorbacks.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=30723&SPID=2419&DB_OEM_ID=6100&ATCLID=183141 Story.] arkansasrazorbacks.com. 11/3/01. Retrieved on August 23, 2008. A tying 32-yard field goal attempt was then set up by [[Eli Manning]]. Razorback fullback Mark Pierce ran in from one yard away to take a 17â10 Arkansas lead in the fourth quarter, but Eli Manning connected with Jamie Armstead to send the game into overtime. Razorback RB [[Cedric Cobbs]] scored from 16 yards out to start the overtime scoring. Eli Manning responded with an 11 yard touchdown pass, sending the game to a second overtime, in which neither team would score. [[Matt Jones (American football)|Matt Jones]] scrambled all 25 yards for the go-ahead touchdown, but the two point run failed. Ole Miss drove to the one yard line, where Joe Gunn ran in. Given a chance to end the game by completing the two point conversion, [[Eli Manning]] threw the ball, but it was incomplete, sending the game to its fourth extra frame. Rebel receiver Bill Flowers hauled in a 21 yard pass from Manning to take the lead, 30â24. After the Rebels failed the two point pass, Jones threw a 24-yard TD pass to [[George Wilson (safety)|George Wilson]]. The Hogs would fail the two point run, extending the game to a fifth overtime. Jones again scored for the Razorbacks, an 8-yard rush, but failed the two point conversion. Manning hit his [[tight end]] Doug Zeigler from twelve yards out, and failed the two point pass. In the sixth overtime, Zeigler again caught a Manning aerial, and Ole Miss connected on the two point conversion with a [[Charles Stackhouse]] rush, taking a 50â42 lead. Razorback Pierce ran in from two yards out, and Arkansas completed the tying two point conversion on a Jones pass. The game would go to a seventh overtime. Mark Pierce again ran in for a two-yard touchdown (his third two-yard score of the game), and Decori Birmingham would receive the two point pass from Jones, making it a 58â50 Hog lead. Manning would throw his sixth touchdown pass, but the two point pass to Doug Ziegler was stopped by Jermaine Petty, giving Arkansas a 58â56 win over [[Arkansas-Ole Miss rivalry|rival]] Ole Miss. The two teams combined for 60 first downs, 130 rushing attempts (80 from the Razorbacks), 68 pass attempts, and 198 total offensive plays, while limiting mistakes, including two fumbles, eight penalties, and one sack. The win moved Arkansas to 5â3 on the year and 3â0 in overtime. Arkansas would play [[2003 Arkansas vs. Kentucky football game|another seven-overtime game]], in 2003. Arkansas ended up winning with a final score of 58â56. Arkansas finished with 531 yards of offense, 370 rushing and 161 passing, while Ole Miss netted 457 yards of offense, 312 passing and 166 rushing. [http://www.hogwired.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=30723&SPID=2419&DB_OEM_ID=6100&ATCLID=183141 Arkansas Downs Ole Miss 58â56 in Seven Overtimes â University of Arkansas Athletics] [http://arsnonline.com/index.php?name=Sections&req=viewarticle&artid=34&allpages=1&theme=Printer Nov 03 2001 â Arkansas 58, Ole Miss 56 :: Arkansas Razorback Sports Network :: Your Online Source for Razorback Football and Basketball] ====2008 â Houston Nutt's first return to Arkansas==== {{Linescore Amfootball | Road = '''Rebels''' |R1=3|R2=10|R3=0|R4=10 | Home = Razorbacks |H1=0|H2=7|H3=0|H4=14 }} '''Ole Miss 23 â Arkansas 21''' {{see also|2008 Ole Miss Rebels football team|2008 Arkansas Razorbacks football team}} On October 25, 2008, Ole Miss returned to [[Donald W. Reynolds Razorback Stadium]] in [[Fayetteville, Arkansas]] for the 55th meeting between the two programs. This was the first game between [[2008 Ole Miss Rebels football team|Ole Miss]] and [[2008 Arkansas Razorbacks football team|Arkansas]] with former Razorback head coach Houston Nutt as the head coach of the Rebels. Ole Miss won the game by a score of 23 to 21. This was the Rebels' first win in the series since 2003. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.hogdb.com/db/opponents/60/Mississippi-series/ List of Arkansas vs Mississippi Games | HogDatabase] {{Arkansas Razorbacks Football}} {{Ole Miss Rebels football navbox}} {{Southeastern Conference football rivalry navbox}} [[Category:College football rivalries in the United States]] [[Category:Arkansas Razorbacks football]] [[Category:Ole Miss Rebels football]]
